headline: Review: Turning the World On, the LSD Way, in ‘The Sunshine Makers’

headline: Review: Horses Under the Hood? In ‘Monster Trucks,’ Try a Cephalopod

headline: Review: In ‘A Different American Dream,’ a Portrait of Resignation

headline: Review: ‘I, Daniel Blake,’ Stuck on the Bureaucratic Hamster Wheel

headline: Review: Another Woman on the Verge in Almodóvar’s ‘Julieta’

headline: Review: Two ‘Passengers’ Trapped on a Spaceship Find Love Amid Despair

headline: Review: God Is Alive and Crabby, According to ‘The Brand New Testament’

headline: Review: In ‘Blue Jay,’ Returning to Romantic Roads Not Taken
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue Jay

headline: Review: In ‘Mirzya,’ Echoes of ‘Romeo and Juliet,’ Lushly Shot
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mirzya

headline: Review: In Henry Jaglom’s ‘Ovation,’ the Action Is Backstage

headline: Review: ‘37,’ a Fictional Retelling of the Kitty Genovese Story

headline: Review: ‘The Great Gilly Hopkins,’ a Child’s Story Elevated by Grown-Ups

headline: Review: ‘The Late Bloomer,’ About a Sex Therapist Who Missed Puberty

headline: Review: Growing Up Fast in ‘London Town’ Amid Punk and Thatcherism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of London Town

headline: Review: In Nate Parker’s ‘The Birth of a Nation,’ Must-See and Won’t-See Collide

headline: Review: In ‘The Girl on the Train,’ a Boozy Emily Blunt Never Winks

headline: Review: ‘M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story’ Recalls a Cricketer’s Ascent
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story

headline: Review: ‘13TH,’ the Journey From Shackles to Prison Bars

display_title: Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children

headline: Review: ‘Harry & Snowman’ Recalls a Man and a Horse of Powerful Haunches

headline: Review: The Animated ‘Long Way North’ Finds a Girl on a Journey

headline: Review: In ‘A Man Called Ove,’ Don’t Let That Scowl Fool You

display_title: The Rolling Stones Olé, Olé, Olé

headline: Review: ‘Masterminds,’ a Tale of Grand Larceny and Meager Gray Matter

display_title: Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story

headline: Review: In ‘Tharlo,’ a Shepherd’s Life Upended by a Trip to the City

headline: Review: ‘Sand Storm’ Follows a Bedouin Mother and Daughter in Quiet Revolts

headline: Review: ‘Chicken People,’ Pampering Royalty That Clucks

headline: Review: An Unflinching Portrayal of Impending Mortality in ‘Chronic’

headline: Review: In ‘Closet Monster,’ a Teenager’s Self-Discovery Is Tinged With Danger

headline: Review: In ‘Queen of Katwe,’ a Pawn Finds Her Crown Through Chess

display_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger

headline: Review: ‘Equals,’ a Futuristic Tale of Defying Deadly Conformity

summary_short: Kristen Stewart and Nicholas Hoult star as workers in a dystopian commune who break the rules by experiencing feelings for each other.

headline: Review: A Sport Comes a Long Way in ‘Free to Run’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free to Run
summary_short: This documentary recounts the extraordinary growth of running, from exclusive clubs to a social revolution on the streets.

headline: Review: A Search for Meaning in ‘Garnet’s Gold’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Garnet’s Gold
summary_short: This documentary by Ed Perkins chronicles a search for a stash of gold, but also ends up telling a larger story about one man’s life.

headline: Review: In ‘How He Fell in Love,’ an Extramarital Bond Unfolds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How He Fell in Love
summary_short: This Marc Meyers film focuses on how the relationship between a young musician and a middle-age woman affects them and others in their orbit.

headline: Review: ‘Outlaws and Angels,’ a Cross Between Western and Home-Invasion Horror
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outlaws and Angels
summary_short: Starring Chad Michael Murray and Clint Eastwood’s daughter Francesca, JT Mollner’s film features outlaws who descend on a seemingly innocent frontier family’s home.

headline: Review: ‘Lucha Mexico’ Offers a Repetitive Look at Pro Wrestlers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucha Mexico
summary_short: This documentary, from Alex Hammond and Ian Markiewicz, introduces the stars of “lucha libre,” the Mexican form of the sport.

headline: Review: In ‘Phantom Boy,’ an Ailing Hero Takes On a Villain
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Phantom Boy
summary_short: This animated film by Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli (“A Cat in Paris”) tells the story of a boy whose illness has given him a gift.

headline: Review: ‘Café Society’ Isn’t Woody Allen’s Worst Movie
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Café Society
summary_short: This ambivalent return to 1930s Hollywood mostly rearranges the director’s old themes. But, overall, it’s an amusing little picture.

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Blink — Robert Frank,’ a Portrait of a Quintessential New York Artist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don’t Blink — Robert Frank
summary_short: Laura Israel’s documentary is less like a full-scale biography than like a magazine profile of Mr. Frank’s long and prodigious career.

headline: Review: In ‘The Infiltrator,’ Bryan Cranston Tunnels Into a Menacing Drug Network
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Infiltrator
summary_short: Based on a memoir, the film depicts a federal agent who poses as a money launderer to combat Pablo Escobar’s cocaine cartel.

display_title: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru
headline: Review: ‘Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru’ Depicts a Self-Help Prophet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru
summary_short: This documentary, an immersive look at one of Mr. Robbins’s Date With Destiny mega-seminars, could pass for a promotional video.

headline: Our ‘Ghostbusters’ Review: Girls Rule. Women Are Funny. Get Over It.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghostbusters
summary_short: This redo lets women, especially Kate McKinnon, be as simply and uncomplicatedly funny as men, and still leaves room for Chris Hemsworth.

headline: Review: Viggo Mortensen Captivates in ‘Captain Fantastic’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain Fantastic
summary_short: Mr. Mortensen is just one of the reasons to see this film about a family forced to leave their home in the woods and become reacquainted with society.

headline: Review: ‘Zero Days’ Examines Cyberwarfare’s Potential Online Apocalypse
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Days
summary_short: This Alex Gibney documentary describes the origin of Stuxnet, malware devised by Israel and the United States with grave implications for the future.

headline: Review: ‘Our Little Sister,’ or What We Found at Dad’s Funeral
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our Little Sister
summary_short: With brilliant narrative stealth, Hirokazu Kore-eda’s film watches as three single women welcome their long-lost teenage half sister into their lives.

headline: Review: Fraternal Dysfunction in the Old South in ‘Men Go to Battle’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Men Go to Battle
summary_short: This film, which takes place during the early years of the Civil War, pushes back against the rigid formality of the period genre.

headline: Review: ‘Fathers and Daughters,’ a Sappy Tale Unredeemed by Star Power
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fathers and Daughters
summary_short: Blunt dialogue and infuriatingly coy storytelling pervade this weepy melodrama starring Amanda Seyfried and Russell Crowe.

display_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates
headline: Review: ‘Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,’ Antics to Not Love nor Cherish
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates
summary_short: This aggressively stupid movie has nothing going for it other than some wasted talent.

display_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You
headline: Review: About Norman Lear, Who Gave Us Archie Bunker
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You
summary_short: The documentary “Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You” is a portrait of the 1970s TV hitmaker who broke ground with issue-oriented humor.

headline: Review: ‘Cell’ Offers Zombified Victims and an Unfocused Narrative
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cell
summary_short: This film, dated, despondent and pretty much a disaster, plays like a series of nods to other science fiction-horror hybrids.

headline: Review: ‘Cold War 2,’ a Brisk Exercise in Hong Kong Suspense
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cold War 2
summary_short: This action film by Longman Leung and Sunny Luk follows the 2012 crime film “Cold War,” a tense, engaging cop thriller.

headline: Review: ‘The Debt’ in This Barney Elliott Film Is a Commodity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Debt
summary_short: Peru’s agricultural landscape is the setting for this film about corporate greed and the persistence of native farmers.

headline: Review: Is the Indian Point Nuclear Plant Safe? Nobody Knows
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Indian Point
summary_short: The documentary “Indian Point,” directed by Ivy Meeropol, focuses on complaints about the safety of this power plant, about 45 miles from Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret Life of Pets’ Amuses, but Misses Opportunities
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret Life of Pets
summary_short: This film is clearly the work of dog people, and traffics — like nearly every other movie in its genre — in some tired anti-feline stereotypes.

headline: Review: In ‘Under the Sun,’ Two Views of North Korea
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Sun
summary_short: Vitaly Mansky’s final film is something different from what his handlers in Pyongyang had in mind.

headline: Review: In ‘The Innocents,’ Not Even Nuns Are Spared War Horrors
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Innocents
summary_short: The film, based on real events in postwar Poland, depicts how atrocities test the faith of Catholic nuns in their own convent.

headline: Review: A House Car? For ‘Microbe and Gasoline,’ It’s Freedom
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Microbe & Gasoline
summary_short: This coming-of-age tale centers on two adolescent outsiders who hit the road in a zany homemade vehicle that doubles as a dwelling.

headline: Review: Once Lost, ‘Private Property’ Is a Genuine Rediscovery
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Private Property
summary_short: This sex-crime thriller from 1960, written and directed by Leslie Stevens, stars Corey Allen and Warren Oates.

headline: Review: A Professor Drawn to the Mob in ‘Our Kind of Traitor’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our Kind of Traitor
summary_short: The film, based on John le Carré’s 2010 novel of the same name, includes complications both geopolitical and conjugal.

headline: Review: ‘The Purge: Election Year’ Offers a Campaign Platform of Blood Lust
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Purge: Election Year
summary_short: In the third chapter of James DeMonaco’s dystopian series, a senator joins insurgents who oppose the yearly overnight killing spree in the title.

headline: Review: In ‘Carnage Park,’ the Hills Have Eyes, and a Sniper, Too
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carnage Park
summary_short: Vivian (Ashley Bell) is taken hostage during a robbery, but that’s just the start of her nightmare in Mickey Keating’s new horror film.

headline: Review: In ‘Life, Animated,’ a Bound Mind Finds Freedom
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life, Animated
summary_short: This documentary, based on Ron Suskind’s book, recounts how Disney films helped his autistic son learn to communicate, and explores his growing up.

headline: Review: Bruce Willis Is a Banker With Issues in ‘Marauders’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marauders
summary_short: In this film, robberies vex Mr. Willis’s character and an F.B.I. agent played by Christopher Meloni.

headline: Review: Revisiting an Unlikely Campaign in ‘Roseanne for President!’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Roseanne for President!
summary_short: Eric Weinrib’s documentary is a fascinating record of Roseanne Barr’s pursuit of a spot on the Green Party’s national ticket in 2012.

headline: Review: A ‘Tarzan’ With a Few Twists in the Hollywood Vine
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Legend of Tarzan
summary_short: Alexander Skarsgard is Tarzan, who returns to the jungle with his man-muscles, in Congo, with an American who believes people are being enslaved.

headline: Review: In ‘The BFG,’ Walking Gently and Wearing Huge Shoes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The BFG
summary_short: In Steven Spielberg’s adaptation of a Roald Dahl story, restraint and Mark Rylance prevail in the face of digital wizardry and belabored wonderment.

headline: Review: In ‘Independence Day: Resurgence,’ the Fault Is Not in the Fireworks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Independence Day: Resurgence
summary_short: All you really need to know about this sequel to the 1996 smash hit is that it took multiple men to cook up this pottage, which hinges on humanity battling aliens.

headline: Review: In ‘Hunt for the Wilderpeople,’ Lighting Out for the Bush
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hunt for the Wilderpeople
summary_short: Taika Waititi’s comedy centers on a foster child in New Zealand first placed with an older couple and then on the run.

headline: Review: In ‘Les Cowboys,’ a Girl Vanishes, and Her Father Can’t Bear It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Les Cowboys
summary_short: Directed by Thomas Bidegain, “Cowboys” uses the narrative codes of the classic western, like John Ford’s “The Searchers,” to tell a modern story.

headline: Review: ‘Three’ Asks, Any Mozart Aficionados in the House?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Three
summary_short: This action-packed crime film by Johnnie To offers mayhem, comical desperation, surreal visuals and compounding excitement. Classical music, too.

headline: Review: ‘From This Day Forward’ Attests to Love’s Adaptability
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From This Day Forward
summary_short: Sharon Shattuck’s documentary tells her family story of growing up with a transgender parent.

display_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words
headline: Review: ‘Eat That Question,’ on Frank Zappa, the Media and Cultural Upheavals
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words
summary_short: A documentary about Zappa is rich in archival interviews that say worlds about this musician — who was well known but not well understood — and his times.

headline: Review: In ‘The Kind Words,’ Siblings and a Secret
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kind Words
summary_short: This film, by the Israeli writer and director Shemi Zarhin, follows a family looking to uncover buried truths.

headline: Review: ‘T-Rex’ Fights Like a Girl. And That’s Worth Gold.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of T-Rex
summary_short: Claressa Shields, the first female boxer to win an Olympic gold medal, is the indomitable center of Drea Cooper and Zackary Canepari’s impressive documentary.

headline: Review: Matthew McConaughey Rebels Against Rebels in ‘Free State of Jones’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free State of Jones
summary_short: Mr. McConaughey plays Newton Knight, the Mississippi farmer who led a dissident Confederate group in the Civil War, and a political coalition after.

headline: Review: ‘Swiss Army Man’ Is a Buddy Movie in Which One Pal Is Dead
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Swiss Army Man
summary_short: Starring Daniel Radcliffe and Paul Dano, this impossible-to-categorize film about a castaway and a corpse is an original mix of the macabre and the magical.

headline: Review: Ranger vs. Preacher? In ‘The Duel,’ It’s No Contest
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Duel
summary_short: Woody Harrelson, who plays a charismatic preacher, delivers a strong performance, but this film is largely characterized by unpersuasive story turns.

headline: Review: In ‘Right Now, Wrong Then,’ a Double Take and Its Choices
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Right Now, Wrong Then
summary_short: The South Korean director Hong Sang-soo twice tells the tale of a first meeting between an older man and younger woman, with different outcomes.

headline: Review: ‘The Shallows’: Surfer Girl. Peckish Shark. Uh-Oh!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Shallows
summary_short: Blake Lively stars as a young woman on a surfing mission in this thriller. But a really, really big shark has its own ravenous plans.

headline: Review: ‘Wiener-Dog,’ the Tail That Wags Through a Few Bitter Lives
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wiener-Dog
summary_short: As usual, Todd Solondz focuses on the awfulness of our species, dramatized in this film through dark, deadpan comic vignettes in the presence of a dachshund.

headline: Review: In ‘The Neon Demon,’ Beauty Masks a Rotting Core
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Neon Demon
summary_short: This puerile movie from the Danish filmmaker Nicolas Winding Refn is set in the high-fashion modeling world of Los Angeles. Elle Fanning and Keanu Reeves star.

headline: Review: In ‘Breaking a Monster,’ a Plea to Play Heavy Metal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breaking a Monster
summary_short: As three black seventh-graders from Brooklyn rise as potential music stars in this documentary, they must face much more than the music.

headline: Review: ‘Septembers of Shiraz’ Revisits the 1979 Iranian Revolution
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Septembers of Shiraz
summary_short: This well-meaning yet nuance-free film focuses on a prosperous and friendly couple targeted for harassment during political upheaval.

headline: Review: In ‘The Phenom,’ Landing on the Couch for Losing the Strike Zone
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Phenom
summary_short: A baseball movie with little baseball, this film asks: When a hot pitching prospect melts down, can an overzealous parent be far behind?

headline: Review: ‘Yarn’: And You Thought It Was Just for Knitting Mittens
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yarn
summary_short: This documentary looks in on people working in yarn, from artists making graffiti to those fashioning playground structures.

headline: Review: ‘Nuts!’ Reveals Doctor’s Secret to Success: Goat Testicle Transplants
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nuts!
summary_short: Penny Lane’s documentary about Dr. John Romulus Brinkley introduces a real-life Kansas con man who claimed to cure impotence with a peculiar kind of surgery.

headline: Review: ‘Clown’ — At Least Bozo Never Ate the Kids
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Clown
summary_short: This horror film, directed by Jon Watts, finds a man putting on a costume — yes, with a red nose — and becoming a possessed killer.

headline: Review: ‘Tickled’ Is Fun and Giggles Until It Isn’t Anymore
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tickled
summary_short: Two filmmakers had barely begun their reporting for this documentary when threats from the private world of tickling began.

display_title: Department Q: a Conspiracy of Faith
headline: Review: ‘A Conspiracy of Faith’ Tracks a Message Written in Blood
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Department Q: a Conspiracy of Faith
summary_short: This thriller is by far the darkest of the Department Q stories. For this pitch-black film trilogy, that’s saying something.

display_title: My Love, Don’t Cross That River
headline: Review: A Couple’s Adoration After 76 Years of Marriage in ‘My Love, Don’t Cross That River’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Love, Don’t Cross That River
summary_short: A film that captures the extraordinary love and profound bond of a couple living in Gangwon Province in South Korea.

headline: Review: In ‘Parched,’ Women in an Indian Village Chafe Against Oppression
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Parched
summary_short: Despite the appalling events it depicts, Leena Yadav’s film has such affection for its female characters that it often achieves a buoyant tone.

headline: Review: In ‘Seoul Searching,’ Teenagers Explore Their Korean Roots to an ’80s Soundtrack
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seoul Searching
summary_short: Set in 1986, the film introduces globally scattered youngsters to their heritage in a plot that both critiques and embraces stereotypes.

display_title: Bang Gang: A Modern Love Story
headline: Review: ‘Bang Gang,’ Seaside Orgies to a Soundtrack of Yawns
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bang Gang: A Modern Love Story
summary_short: This film about middle-class teenagers having group sex during a long hot summer in Biarritz, France, is remarkable for its shrugging attitude.

headline: Review: ‘Cosmos’ Is a Madcap Plunge Into Retro Avant-Gardism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cosmos
summary_short: The Polish director Andrzej Zulawski’s final film is a witty and energetic — if somewhat labored — mélange of styles and ideas in a cosmopolitan mode.

display_title: Raiders: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made
headline: Review: In ‘Raiders!,’ Two Boys’ First, Great Movie Crush
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Raiders: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made
summary_short: In 1982, two Mississippi boys set out to create a shot-by-shot remake of Steven Spielberg’s “Raiders of the Lost Ark.” This is their story.

headline: Review: In ‘Argentina,’ a Call to Save Traditions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Argentina
summary_short: Carlos Saura’s film captures a wide array of artists as they perform the folk music and dances of Argentina.

headline: Review: In ‘Central Intelligence,’ a Weaponized Kevin Hart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Central Intelligence
summary_short: This espionage comedy, which also stars Dwayne Johnson, accomplishes its mission of being aggressively juvenile.

display_title: Department Q: The Keeper of Lost Causes
headline: Review: ‘The Keeper of Lost Causes,’ Pitch-Black Nordic Noir
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Department Q: The Keeper of Lost Causes
summary_short: Detective Carl Morck has one mood, and boy, it’s bad. The film, based on a novel by Jussi Adler-Olsen, is part of “The Department Q Trilogy.”

headline: Review: ‘Land and Shade,’ Set Among Colombia’s Sugar Farmers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Land and Shade
summary_short: A Colombian farmer returns home after years away to be with his ill son in this film, which won best first feature at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.

display_title: 2016 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour
headline: Review: Sundance Film Festival Short Films, a Group of Hits and Misses
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2016 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour
summary_short: A touring program from this year’s lineup, including “The Procedure,” “Bacon & God’s Wrath,” “Justice” and more, is opening at the IFC Center.

headline: Review: In ‘Finding Dory,’ a Forgetful Fish and a Warm Celebration of Differences
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Dory
summary_short: The friendly blue fish with short-term memory problems goes looking for her family and takes a star turn in this sequel to “Finding Nemo.”

headline: Review: ‘Call Her Applebroog,’ Beth B’s Portrait of a Still-Vital Artist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Call Her Applebroog
summary_short: Beth B, Ida Applebroog’s daughter, takes an intimate look at the artist’s drawings, paintings and emphatic engagement with others.

headline: Review: In ‘Len and Company,’ a Prickly Pop Producer Finds His Solitude Interrupted
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Len and Company
summary_short: Rhys Ifans stars as a disaffected former rock star who retreats to the countryside after a meltdown, only to host some surprise guests with concerns of their own.

headline: Review: In ‘King Jack,’ a 15-Year-Old Trapped in a Cycle of Bullying
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of King Jack
summary_short: Felix Johnson’s coming-of-age story portrays a teenage boy in a small town in which a bully exercises his capacity for cruelty.

headline: Review: In ‘The Conjuring 2,’ Ghostly Violence Has a British Accent
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Conjuring 2
summary_short: James Wan’s sequel to his horror hit concerns a London poltergeist in 1977. Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson return as paranormal investigators.

headline: Review: Brian De Palma Says He Is Hitchcock’s True Heir
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of De Palma
summary_short: In the documentary “De Palma,” Mr. De Palma explores his muse, and the juxtaposition of images from both of their works goes beyond glib shorthand.

headline: Review: ‘Genius’ Puts Max Perkins and Thomas Wolfe in a Literary Bromance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Genius
summary_short: Michael Grandage’s 1930s-era biopic is nostalgia for a supposed golden age of masculine artistic potency.

headline: Review: ‘Careful What You Wish For,’ Starring Nick Jonas as a Naïve Teenage Lover
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Careful What You Wish For
summary_short: Elizabeth Allen’s film casts Mr. Jonas as a boy who takes up with the beautiful woman next door in a summer idyll that proves anything but.

headline: Review: ‘Germans & Jews,’ a New Generation Continues a Difficult Conversation
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Germans & Jews
summary_short: In Janina Quint’s documentary, a group of Jewish and non-Jewish Germans, most of them born after World War II, reckon with the past.

headline: Review: ‘Puerto Ricans in Paris’ Combines Comedy and Crime
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Puerto Ricans in Paris
summary_short: Two New York police officers get a break from their home lives when they are asked to help stop a counterfeiter in France.

headline: Review: Taking the Long Way Home in ‘Last Cab to Darwin’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Cab to Darwin
summary_short: A dying man who works as a cabby longs to leave the world on his own terms, so he turns the wheel toward eternity.

headline: Review: ‘Now You See Me 2’ Illusionists Are Out to Save the World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Now You See Me 2
summary_short: The sleight-of-hand the Four Horsemen must pull off in this cartoonish movie, directed by Jon M. Chu, would protect everyone’s computers.

headline: Review: In ‘Be Somebody,’ a Teenage Idol Goes AWOL With an Ordinary Girl
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Be Somebody
summary_short: Matthew Espinosa plays a pop star who has had enough with his tour handlers and sees how the other folks live.

headline: Review: ‘The Music of Strangers,’ on Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Music of Strangers
summary_short: Morgan Neville’s documentary follows the ensemble and discusses the relevance of music in a violent world. Lovely to watch, it’s even more beautiful to hear.

headline: Review: In ‘Therapy for a Vampire,’ the Count Really Wants to Change
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Therapy for a Vampire
summary_short: Sigmund Freud takes a vampire as a patient in this comedy written and directed by David Ruehm.

headline: Review: In ‘Tikkun,’ a Hasidic Student’s Visions Merge With Metaphor
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tikkun
summary_short: This feature from the Israeli director Avishai Sivan employs fanciful imagery in dark but often funny ways, without abandoning empathy.

headline: Review: ‘Diary of a Chambermaid’ Stars Léa Seydoux as an Abused Maid
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diary of a Chambermaid
summary_short: Taking a period role memorably played by Paulette Goddard and Jeanne Moreau, Ms. Seydoux evokes the mutual loathing of the haves and have-nots.

headline: Review: In ‘Warcraft,’ Orcs of a Different Domain, Fighting With Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Warcraft
summary_short: Directed by Duncan Jones, this cinematic extension of the brand that began as a video game features invading orcs, embattled humans and much pummeling.

headline: Review: ‘’Til Madness Do Us Part’ Finds Hell and Humanity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 'Til Madness Do Us Part
summary_short: Wang Bing’s documentary about a mental hospital in China is overlong but sporadically extraordinary.

headline: Review: ‘From Afar,’ a Tale of Desire and Repression in Venezuela
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Afar
summary_short: A middle-aged gay man who lures young men from the streets develops an unlikely friendship with a tough, handsome teenager.

headline: Review: In ‘The Fits,’ a Graceful Tale of a Girl Who Follows Her Own Beat
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fits
summary_short: This debut feature from Anna Rose Holmer centers on an 11-year-old tomboy who trains as a boxer only to discover an interest in joining an all-female dance team.

headline: Review: ‘Art Bastard’ Depicts Robert Cenedella, a Rebel Artist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Art Bastard
summary_short: This documentary zeros in on a painter who defied art-world conventions with teeming satirical paintings.

headline: Review: ‘Time to Choose’ Extols Renewable Energy to Combat Global Warming
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Time to Choose
summary_short: Charles Ferguson’s documentary is a sobering polemic about climate change that balances predictions of planetary doom with a survey of innovations in energy technology.

headline: Review: ‘The Final Master,’ a Martial Arts Story of Transitions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Final Master
summary_short: A kung fu master seeks a wife and a place to teach in Tianjin, and finds what he needs, if not what he was looking for.

display_title: The Thoughts That Once We Had
headline: Review: ‘The Thoughts That Once We Had,’ a Cinematic Flight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Thoughts That Once We Had
summary_short: A montage of film clips that takes us on a wild ride through cinematic history.

headline: Review: ‘The Wailing’ Will Scare You, and Break Your Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wailing
summary_short: Na Hong-jin’s movie about demonic possession is an expansive and often excruciating horror film from South Korea.

headline: Review: ‘The Witness,’ a Brother’s Quest to Put Kitty Genovese Case to Rest
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Witness
summary_short: James Solomon’s documentary traces Bill Genovese’s efforts to unravel his sister’s 1964 murder, a Queens case long seen as the epitome of urban apathy.

headline: Review: In ‘Me Before You,’ a Broken Man Meets a Free Spirit
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Me Before You

summary_short: Peter Jackson concludes his trilogy treatment of J. R. R. Tolkien’s “The Hobbit” with a film devoted to warfare and driven by greed.

headline: Stumbling Into Divorce
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye to All That
summary_short: “Goodbye to All That” tracks an amiably self-centered guy (Paul Schneider) through a divorce and the perils of Internet dating.

headline: The Bloom Is Off the Rose, the Cap Off the Toothpaste
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arrête ou je continue
summary_short: Sophie Fillières’s “If You Don’t, I Will” looks at an unhappy French couple (Emmanuelle Devos and Mathieu Amalric) living in too-close quarters.

headline: The Upside of Magical Thinking
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Feet
summary_short: In Alexandre Rockwell’s “Little Feet,” two motherless Los Angeles children deal resourcefully with the death of a pet fish.

headline: Noir Days of Sun, Los Angeles Smog and Marijuana Haze
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inherent Vice
summary_short: “Inherent Vice,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s adaptation of the Thomas Pynchon novel, is a labyrinthine noir set in sunny Los Angeles, circa 1970.

headline: One Man’s Crisis of the Soul (It’s a Comedy)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Top Five
summary_short: In “Top Five,” Chris Rock and a rich lineup of fellow comedians tell the story of an actor who wrestles with his identity as he tries his hand at a serious film.

headline: The Eyes of a Beholder of Hardship
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Salt of the Earth
summary_short: “The Salt of the Earth,” a film by Wim Wenders and Juliano Ribeiro Salgado, illustrates the way Sebastião Salgado’s photographs create beauty by capturing pain, violence and deprivation.

headline: Agitating for Change in the Face of Tyranny
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are The Giant
summary_short: “We Are the Giant,” an Arab Spring documentary by Greg Barker, profiles seven charismatic activists agitating for change in Libya, Syria and Bahrain.

headline: A Delusion and a Dream House Share Space
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Theo's House
summary_short: In “Theo’s House,” Hannu-Pekka Bjorkman is an architect with regrets and a dream project.

headline: 12 at the Easel, Painting a Poet’s Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Color of Time
summary_short: “The Color of Time,” a montage of the life of the poet C. K. Williams, features James Franco and Jessica Chastain.

headline: Stockholm Syndrome, With an Overlay of Wintry Ontario
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Captive
summary_short: In Atom Egoyan’s gray-tinged “The Captive,” a couple’s relationship frays after a man abducts their daughter, and detectives have difficulty solving the case.

headline: A Coming-of-Age Tale on Ice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skating to New York
summary_short: “Skating to New York” follows four Canadian high school friends and a kid brother who spend one of the coldest days of the year trying to skate across Lake Ontario.

headline: So Many Faces Make Up One Crowd
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maidan
summary_short: The documentary “Maidan,” filmed during protests in Ukraine, focuses on the physical movement of crowds.

headline: Internal Affairs Police Who Don’t Confine Snooping to Work
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tip Top
summary_short: In “Tip Top,” a pair of internal affairs officers in France bring their personal eccentricities to their investigation of the death of an informant from Algeria.

display_title: Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks
headline: Ms. Self-Pity, Meet Mr. Self-Destructive
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks
summary_short: “Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks” is an odd-couple comedy about a prim older woman and her dance teacher, a young gay man.

headline: Going Topless as a Cause
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free the Nipple
summary_short: “Free the Nipple,” directed by Lina Esco, presents itself as part of a broader movement that advocates for a woman’s right to go topless in public.

headline: A Comedic Sprinter Tries a Marathon
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Expelled
summary_short: “Expelled” features Cameron Dallas, a star of Vine, the site of six-second videos, as a student trying to hide his expulsion from high school.

headline: Moses Is Back, Bearing Tablets and Strange Accents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exodus: Gods And Kings
summary_short: “Exodus: Gods and Kings” is Ridley Scott’s attempt to bring a famous chunk of the Hebrew Bible to life in 3-D.

display_title: Do You Know What My Name Is?
headline: Putting a Face on Memory Loss and Recovery
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Do You Know What My Name Is?
summary_short: A documentary presents a treatment for Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia, while it offers profiles of people suffering from the disease.

headline: A Chess Knight and a Lonely Little Damsel
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Little Game
summary_short: In “A Little Game,” a curmudgeonly chess player in Washington Square Park helps a 10-year-old who is mocked at school for her lack of chess knowledge.

headline: Goody-Two-Shoes Loses His Footing
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After the Fall
summary_short: An insurance agent who was fired from his job turns to a life of crime to support his family in Saar Klein’s “After the Fall.”

display_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles
headline: A Movie Legend’s Long Run
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles
summary_short: In “Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles,” the director Chuck Workman examines that ambitious filmmaker.

headline: Don’t Say That Word (It Might Come True)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pyramid
summary_short: An archaeological team and a documentary crew get stuck in an ancient Egyptian tomb in “The Pyramid,” starring Denis O’Hare and Ashley Hinshaw.

headline: Telling Lies for Love, Cruelty or Expediency
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Risate di Gioia
summary_short: A restored version of Mario Monicelli’s 1960 film, “The Passionate Thief,” is having its first New York theatrical run at Film Forum.

headline: In the Samurai Business, We Used to Do Our Own Stunts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uzumasa Limelight
summary_short: “Uzumasa Limelight,” directed by Ken Ochiai, tells the story of one of the “kirareyaku,” old-school samurai actors, at the end of his career.

headline: No Midnight Cowgirl
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Foxy Merkins
summary_short: A lesbian prostitute and her heterosexual mentor in sex work experience comic adventures around New York in “The Foxy Merkins,” which has the tone of an absurdist buddy comedy.

headline: An Intercessor, Straddling Two Families
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Barefoot Artist
summary_short: Lily Yeh, whose work aims to heal communities, aims for more personal healing in the documentary “The Barefoot Artist.”

headline: Nursing Real Wounds, and Romantic Ones
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take Care
summary_short: In the rom-com “Take Care,” a woman injured in a car accident and needing help managing her daily life calls on an old boyfriend.

headline: Arms Locked, and Awakening to Their Strength
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of She's Beautiful When She's Angry
summary_short: With interviews and historical footage, “She’s Beautiful When She’s Angry” surveys a heady period in the late ’60s when women organized to demand their rights.

headline: When a Marriage Goes South
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Knot
summary_short: In “Red Knot,” a newlywed couple voyaging to Antarctica confront stresses in their marriage.

headline: A Roiling Sea of Corruption and Paranoia
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pioneer
summary_short: The Norwegian thriller “Pioneer” focuses on an oil exploration worker who develops deep suspicions about his employer.

headline: A Pet Dies, and the Fun Begins
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Murder of a Cat
summary_short: “Murder of a Cat,” in which a man tries to solve the mystery of the death of his pet, is a quirky variation on the private eye theme.

headline: Class Warfare at the Most Intimate Level
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Julie
summary_short: Liv Ullmann’s version of Strindberg’s “Miss Julie” features Jessica Chastain and Colin Farrell as class-bound lovers repelled and attracted by each other in a battle of the sexes.

display_title: A Spell to Ward Off the Darkness
headline: Feeling Your Way Toward Utopia
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Spell to Ward Off the Darkness
summary_short: “A Spell to Ward Off the Darkness” harnesses the formal properties of film to ponder ways of engaging with the world.

headline: Best Friends Forever, Till a Boyfriend Arrives
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life Partners
summary_short: A lifelong friendship between two women is put to the test when one of them falls in love in “Life Partners.”

headline: Losing Her Bearings in Familiar Places
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still Alice
summary_short: In “Still Alice,” Julianne Moore plays a Columbia linguistics professor who receives a devastating diagnosis.

headline: A Cat and a Mouse, Both Slipping but Still at Odds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dying of the Light
summary_short: In “Dying of the Light,” a C.I.A. operative is determined to chase down a terrorist who the agency says is already dead.

headline: A Has-Been Conjures a Second Act
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delusions of Guinevere
summary_short: In “Delusions of Guinevere,” a former child actress uses social media to get attention.

headline: Reverberations of a Subjugated Past
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Concerning Violence
summary_short: In “Concerning Violence,” Goran Hugo Olsson uses archival clips, texts by the scholar Frantz Fanon and voice-overs by musicians to revisit anticolonialist struggles of the 20th century.

headline: Romance on the Edge of Intersecting Dimensions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Comet
summary_short: “Comet,” the feature debut of the director Sam Esmail, deconstructs love, time and probability.

headline: Unwinding an Artist and His Demons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Billy Bates
summary_short: In “Billy Bates,” a singer helps a tortured artist work through his problems.

headline: Walking With Solitude, and Her Baggage
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild
summary_short: “Wild” stars Reese Witherspoon as a woman who takes on an arduous solo trek along the Pacific Crest Trail.

headline: Where the Biggest Enemy Is Tedium
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Motivation
summary_short: The Israeli comedy “Zero Motivation” looks at the monotony of life for two young female soldiers assigned to a remote desert outpost.

headline: Raising a Defiant Hand Against the Fist of the Law
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ungli
summary_short: In “Ungli,” four young professionals — led by Kangana Ranaut and Randeep Hooda — set out to avenge the aggrieved and the powerless amid widespread malfeasance in Mumbai.

headline: Go Read a Book, Kid. It Couldn’t Hurt You.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Babadook
summary_short: “The Babadook,” the Australian director Jennifer Kent’s debut feature, is a horror movie full of interlocking ambiguities.

headline: When Fractions of a Second Can Change Whole Lives
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Touch the Wall
summary_short: The documentary “Touch the Wall” follows two world-class swimmers, Kara Lynn Joyce and Missy Franklin.

headline: From Here (or There) to Eternity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Immortalists
summary_short: “The Immortalists,” a documentary directed by David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg, looks at two scientists racing against time and its inevitable consequences.

headline: Broken Codes, Both Strategic and Social
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Imitation Game
summary_short: In “The Imitation Game” Benedict Cumberbatch plays Alan Turing, whose code-breaking work helped win World War II yet whose homosexuality led him to face indecency charges in Britain.

headline: Who Knew the Classics Could Be So Combative?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Historian
summary_short: “The Historian” centers on a divorced professor who clashes with a superior and walks an ethical tightrope.

headline: A Doctor Will See You Now
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Remote Area Medical
summary_short: “Remote Area Medical” chronicles a nonprofit group that stages free clinics in areas that lack access to basic health care.

headline: Slashing His Wrists When the Phone Rings
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Disappear
summary_short: “Before I Disappear” is Shawn Christensen’s feature-length expansion of his Oscar-winning short, “Curfew.”

headline: Home Sweet Home on the Isolated Ice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antarctica: A Year On Ice
summary_short: The documentary “Antarctica” reveals the community spirit among residents of the southernmost continent.

headline: A Task Force in Black Tuxedos
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Penguins of Madagascar
summary_short: In the animated “Penguins of Madagascar,” the title animals will lose their cuteness if an octopus named Dave (voiced by John Malkovich) has his way.

headline: Underlings Again Seek the Upper Hand
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Horrible Bosses 2
summary_short: An invention is part of the plot of “Horrible Bosses 2,” a sequel that tries to recapture the zany feel of the original film.

headline: A Secret Falls From the Family Tree, and a Girl’s Identity Branches Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little White Lie
summary_short: In the documentary “Little White Lie,” a girl who grew up viewing herself as Jewish and white gradually begins to realize that her biological father was black.

headline: Charles XVI: An Inept Hunter, but You Can Count on Him
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Roi et l'oiseau
summary_short: A restored version of the animated “The King and the Mockingbird,” an adaptation of a Hans Christian Andersen story, has a New York run.

headline: Sifting the Ashes of Bible Belt Church Fires
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Hope Was Arson
summary_short: Theo Love’s “Little Hope Was Arson” looks at the scars inflicted by 10 church fires over five weeks.

headline: The Old Country Never Goes Away
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stones in the Sun

headline: A Restless and Turbulent Unconscious
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sleepwalker
summary_short: “The Sleepwalker” is a spare study of two couples that digs into issues about class, domestic abuse, sibling rivalry and mental illness, but refrains from easy answers.

headline: Up From Rubble to Lead a Revolution
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Part 1
summary_short: The latest installment of the “Hunger Games” films is a vague yet stirring liberation story that echoes real-life struggles against oppression around the world.

headline: A Secret Life in Zurich
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Der Kreis
summary_short: Stefan Haupt’s “The Circle” tells the story of a gay Swiss couple, from their (dramatized) meeting in the 1950s to documentary interviews today.

headline: Smoldering Dance, Unadorned
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flamenco, Flamenco
summary_short: “Flamenco Flamenco,” by Carlos Saura, presents performances by some of the great ones of the field.

headline: Chapter 6 Has Great Advice for Gangsters
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reach Me
summary_short: A self-help guide affects a large ensemble of characters in “Reach Me,” set in the greater Los Angeles area.

display_title: Monk With A Camera: The Life and Journey of Nicholas Vreeland
headline: A Holy Man in India, Descended From New York Fashion
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monk With A Camera: The Life and Journey of Nicholas Vreeland
summary_short: Nicholas Vreeland, a grandson of the fashion editor Diana Vreeland and the leader of a Buddhist monastery in India, is profiled in “Monk With a Camera.”

headline: Get Off My Lawn, Werewolf
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Late Phases
summary_short: In “Late Phases,” Nick Damici stars as a blind Vietnam veteran taking on a retirement village’s supernatural foe.

headline: In for a Penny, in for a Pound, and Better Work Conditions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Food Chains
summary_short: “Food Chains” is a documentary of a labor struggle waged by workers who each bring hundreds of pounds of tomatoes to market each day.

headline: Close Encounters of the Woodsy, Slasher Kind
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Extraterrestrial
summary_short: Directed by Colin Minihan, “Extraterrestrial” draws on themes and bits from other films for its tale of malevolent aliens.

headline: Making Music, Not War
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death Metal Angola

headline: Another Kind of Mystery Date
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All Relative
summary_short: Having two relationships at once causes complications for a graduate student in the comedy “All Relative.”

headline: An Orientation in Several Shades
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 4 Moons
summary_short: “4 Moons” is Sergio Tovar Velarde’s look at gay boys and men in today’s Mexico.

display_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone At Night
headline: A Redesign of Dracula’s Cape
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Girl Walks Home Alone At Night
summary_short: A Persian-speaking, chador-wearing vampire is the main character in Ana Lily Amirpour’s “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.”

headline: Legendary Seducers, Meeting in the Twilight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Historia de la meva mort
summary_short: In “Story of My Death,” the director and writer Albert Serra imagines the paths crossing of the hedonistic Casanova and a bloodthirsty Dracula.

headline: A Power Struggle, Roots and All
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pelo Malo
summary_short: In “Bad Hair,” a Venezuelan boy’s ideas about his appearance add to his mother’s troubles.

headline: Fanfare for the Common Man (and a Band)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pulp
summary_short: “Pulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets” is a documentary that returns to Sheffield, England, hometown of that alternative rock band, which had its heyday in the 1990s.

headline: Tarnished Halos at Penn State
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy Valley
summary_short: Joe Paterno, college football and the world of State College, Pa., home to Penn State, are examined in “Happy Valley,” a documentary built around the Jerry Sandusky child abuse case.

headline: Conditioned to Destroy, but Then a Softening
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill Dil
summary_short: In “Kill Dil,” set in India, a woman steps into the lives of two men raised to be killers.

headline: Plain on the Plains
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Homesman
summary_short: In “The Homesman,” Hilary Swank and Tommy Lee Jones help three women driven to madness by the frontier get back East.

headline: Taken Down by Twisted Ambition
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Foxcatcher
summary_short: Starring Steve Carell and Channing Tatum, “Foxcatcher,” directed by Bennett Miller, tells the true-crime story of an Olympic wrestler and his multimillionaire sponsor.

headline: Just After Lake Placid, Things Improved
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Army
summary_short: Gabe Polsky’s documentary, “Red Army,” follows Soviet hockey stars from Olympic glory days to a second act with the National Hockey League.

headline: Cruising for Fares, a Song in His Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Hunter
summary_short: The Serbian film “Love Hunter” centers on an ambitious Serbian musician trying to succeed in New York while making ends meet as a cabdriver.

headline: The Glamorous Life, With All Its Woes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond the Lights
summary_short: In Gina Prince-Bythewood’s “Beyond the Lights,” a pop star lives a lonely life before meeting a police officer with ambitions of his own.

headline: Beyond the Casting Couch. Way Beyond.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starry Eyes
summary_short: Giving in to a lecher might help a young actress get her foot in the door, but when the soul follows, as it does in “Starry Eyes,” the trouble begins.

headline: A Journalist Imprisoned in Iran, Escaping With Ghosts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rosewater
summary_short: “Rosewater,” from Jon Stewart, tells the story of an Iranian-born journalist who was arrested in Iran in 2009 and accused of being an agent for foreign intelligence organizations.

headline: The Seeds of an Urban Protest
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Occupy the Farm
summary_short: “Occupy the Farm,” directed by Todd Darling, looks at a 2012 grass-roots standoff over plans to sell a section of farmland owned by the University of California.

headline: A Teacher on a Mission to Erase Evil
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Meadows
summary_short: There is more under the surface than a moviegoer might guess on first glance at “Miss Meadows,” whose title character is played by Katie Holmes.

display_title: Levitated Mass: The Story of Michael Heizer's Monolithic Sculpture
headline: Surreal Journey of a Rock That Would Be Art
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Levitated Mass: The Story of Michael Heizer's Monolithic Sculpture
summary_short: “Levitated Mass” chronicles the transport of a 340-ton boulder through Southern California to a sculptor’s installation at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: Cursed by Guilt and a Creepy Sense That Punishment Is Coming
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Penance
summary_short: Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s “Penance” follows four young women who were traumatized by a classmate’s murder and by their own puzzling failure to identify the killer.

headline: To Save Us All From Satan’s Power
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kirk Cameron's Saving Christmas
summary_short: In “Kirk Cameron’s Saving Christmas,” Mr. Cameron stages his version of an intervention to bolster seasonal cheer and put the Bible back in the holidays.

headline: When the ‘Pure-Blood’ Sort Are Cannibals
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wolves
summary_short: In “Wolves,” directed by David Hayter, a teenager awakens from a terrible dream to find that his parents have been killed and that he is acquiring lupine form.

headline: Like a Wiser Dorothy’s Yen for Kansas
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Always Woodstock
summary_short: “Always Woodstock” centers on an aspiring singer-songwriter who strikes out in New York City and moves back to her childhood home.

headline: Then We Could Swing a Cat From a Chandelier
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dumb and Dumber To
summary_short: “Dumb and Dumber To” reunites Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels, adds Kathleen Turner and relies heavily on diaper gags.

display_title: Drug Lord: The Legend Of Shorty
headline: On the Trail of a Fearsome Escape Artist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drug Lord: The Legend Of Shorty
summary_short: In “Drug Lord: The Legend of Shorty,” filmmakers set out to find the kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, obtaining remarkable access to insiders in Mexico’s criminal culture.

headline: The Woods Are Dark and So, So Deep
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Butter on the Latch
summary_short: Two movies directed by Josephine Decker, “Butter on the Latch” and “Thou Wast Mild & Lovely,” revel in cryptic lyricism.

headline: Like Father, Unlike Son
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brahmin Bulls
summary_short: “Brahmin Bulls,” Mahesh Pailoor’s debut feature, is a father-and-son story that hinges on an interesting complication of sympathies.

headline: Let the Drinking Games and Self-Pity Begin
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beside Still Waters
summary_short: In Chris Lowell’s “Beside Still Waters,” a weekend reunion of old high school friends turns into whiskey-lubricated nostalgia.

headline: Cotton Mills, Venom and Dead Ends
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Turn Worse
summary_short: Zeke and Simon Hawkins’s “Bad Turn Worse” begins with $20,000 missing from a safe in a Texas cotton mill town.

headline: Gorillas in the Midst of a Battle Over Oil
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Virunga
summary_short: In “Virunga,” a national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo with rare mountain gorillas is a battleground over oil drilling and conservation.

headline: Matters of the (Young) Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hoje Eu Quero Voltar Sozinho
summary_short: A young man who happens to be blind begins to indulge his independence and understand his sexuality in “The Way He Looks.”

headline: It’s a Plane! No, It’s a Bird
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pelican Dreams
summary_short: “Pelican Dreams” is a study of California’s brown pelicans by Judy Irving, the director of “The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill.”

headline: A Director’s Gift
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 21 Years: Richard Linklater
summary_short: “21 Years: Richard Linklater,” by Michael Dunaway and Tara Wood, offers a star-studded tribute to the director of “Boyhood,” “School of Rock” and “Slacker.”

display_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell?
headline: When Yakuza Meets the Movies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Why Don't You Play in Hell?
summary_short: A starlet from a crime family, an aimless movie director and lots of violent types populate Sion Sono’s “Why Don’t You Play in Hell?”

headline: From the Lips of Desperate Poles in ’44
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Powstanie Warszawskie
summary_short: “Warsaw Uprising” harnesses archival film from that World War II resistance battle, even using actors to recite what on-camera subjects might have been saying.

headline: A Politician Slips, and an Ideal Impostor Steps In
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Viva la libertà
summary_short: In “Viva la Libertà,” a twin impersonates his brother, a politician who has dropped out of sight.

headline: Only One Sugar Plum Fairy a Year
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Getting to the Nutcracker
summary_short: Serene Meshel-Dillman’s documentary “Getting to ‘The Nutcracker’ ” focuses on the Marat Daukayev School of Ballet in Los Angeles.

headline: Behind Closed Doors in Both Berlins
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Der Turm
summary_short: Christian Schwochow’s dramas “The Tower” and “West” deal with paranoia in East and West Berlin for very different people in different decades.

headline: Crushed by a Giant, With No White Knight in Sight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invisible Front
summary_short: The documentary “The Invisible Front” centers on Lithuania’s quixotic postwar struggle to escape Soviet dominion.

headline: Lincoln, the Beardless, Ethereal Youth

summary_short: In “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” Wolverine is sent back to the 1970s to round up his young colleagues to help prevent an apocalyptic battle a half-century away.

headline: Monsters (the Human Kind) Slithering Through East Texas

summary_short: In “Cold in July,” Michael C. Hall, Sam Shepard and Don Johnson are unlikely amigos, banding against evil.

headline: The Plagiarist’s Love Interest

summary_short: In the German romantic comedy “Lila, Lila,” a waiter (Daniel Brühl) finds a manuscript and passes it off as his own to impress a young woman.

headline: We Feel Your Vibe
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frequencies
summary_short: “Frequencies,” written and directed by Darren Paul Fisher, is a sci-fi film with a surreal twist on real life.

headline: ‘Home’ for the Summer, in a Refugee Camp

headline: When Single Parents Collide on a Safari

headline: She’s Just Off the Boat. He’s the Wrong Man.

headline: What Lewis and Clark Inspired
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Discoverers
summary_short: In “The Discoverers,” a history professor takes his children on a family-fraught trip with historical re-enactors.

headline: On the Range, With a Conscience

summary_short: Kirk Hanna, the focus of the documentary “Hanna Ranch,” appeared in “Fast Food Nation.”

headline: Love, Sex, Marriage and Schopenhauer’s Ghost
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chinese Puzzle
summary_short: “Chinese Puzzle,” the third film in a trilogy, centers on a womanizing Frenchman who follows his ex-wife to New York.

headline: A Menace Who Chops Up Bodies and Enjoys a Good Singalong
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wolf Creek 2

headline: After an Accident, a Test of Forgiveness

headline: Attending Life’s First Breath and Its Last
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The American Nurse
summary_short: The documentary “The American Nurse,” a tribute to the profession, focuses on five who work across life’s spectrum, from labor and delivery to hospice.

headline: Foreclosed, Cantankerous and Heading South

headline: Travelers Move Past Their Own Limits
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Next Year Jerusalem

headline: Hapless Meal Tickets, Plucked From India
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Million Dollar Arm
summary_short: “Million Dollar Arm” centers on a self-centered sports agent who recruits potential major league pitchers in India.

headline: Still Radioactive and Spoiling for a Fight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Godzilla

headline: Tilting at Genres
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don Peyote
summary_short: Dan Fogler stars in “Don Peyote,” which he wrote and directed with Michael Canzoniero.

headline: The Internet Isn’t Just for the Young

headline: In Nigeria, the Personal and the Political Clash

headline: A Depressed Writer, Distracted by His Ailing Parents

headline: Telling the Gypsies’ Tale Beyond the Stereotype

summary_short: “A People Uncounted” focuses on how Gypsies, as people known as the Roma are called, have been disenfranchised and persecuted.

headline: Challenging Authority and Taking the Heat

headline: Where Hope Is Scarce, Terrorism Takes Root

headline: Seeing God in Snakes, Strippers and Tattoos
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Jesus
summary_short: Aram Garriga’s documentary “American Jesus” samples the outliers of Christianity in the United States.

headline: A Teenage Tone Poem, Balancing Fear With Rash Impulses
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Palo Alto

headline: Sugar, Come Out With Your Hands Up

summary_short: In “Fed Up,” a documentary investigation into why people are getting fatter, the filmmakers explore who’s killing our health.

headline: More Tales of the ‘Righteous’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rescuers

headline: Competing Against a Doppelgänger Who Spells Trouble

headline: Dad’s Watching Us? Call Social Services
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moms' Night Out
summary_short: In “Moms’ Night Out,” hapless fathers assume command after the women in their lives decide that they need a restaurant outing.

headline: Wicked Witch Is Dead, but Here Comes a Jester
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Legends of Oz: Dorothy's Return
summary_short: A cast of familiar characters embarks on a rescue mission in the animated “Legends of Oz: Dorothy’s Return.”

headline: Cracking a Safe of Painful Memories
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chapman
summary_short: “Chapman” centers on a young man who travels home to Colorado for a funeral and confronts his adolescent past.

headline: First a Killing, Then a Code of Silence
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of God's Pocket
summary_short: “God’s Pocket,” a star-studded drama set in Philadelphia, is the actor John Slattery’s feature film directorial debut.

headline: Young Hands Steering the Family Tractor

summary_short: “Farmland,” a documentary by James Moll, profiles six family farms and the young people who now run them.

headline: Three Boys Entangled in Mass Hysteria

headline: A Plea to Let Those Waters Flow

summary_short: The documentary “DamNation” argues against human interference with rivers.

headline: Man in the Kitchen Is Hungry for Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chef

headline: The Theater of Tough Beginnings
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still I Strive
summary_short: Part documentary and part fictional entertainment, “Still I Strive” takes viewers inside a Cambodian orphanage.

headline: Just Try Borrowing a Cup of Sugar
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Neighbors

headline: An Artist Who Let His Ideas (and Others) Do the Work

headline: A Portrait of the Outsider Artist, Older and Still Unfiltered

headline: Tiny Mouths to Feed, a Path Often Fraught
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breastmilk
summary_short: “Breastmilk,” an agenda-free documentary by Dana Ben-Ari, observes the nursing journeys of five new mothers in New York City.

headline: Done In by Décolletage and Defeatism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walk of Shame
summary_short: In “Walk of Shame,” Elizabeth Banks plays a TV newswoman who applies for a job in New York, assumes she did not get it and goes out on a night on the town that leads to a run of bad luck.

headline: An Innocent Awakened

display_title: Speak the Music: Robert Mann and the Mysteries of Chamber Music
headline: A Life in a String Quartet, and Beyond
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Speak the Music: Robert Mann and the Mysteries of Chamber Music
summary_short: Robert Mann, a violinist and founding member of the Juilliard String Quartet, had to maintain a student’s outlook in his half-century with the group.

display_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage
headline: Kevin Spacey and Company Hit the Road
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage

headline: A Man and His Elephant, and Flying Fists
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Protector 2
summary_short: A sequel to “The Protector” revolves around another kidnapping of the sacred elephant Khon.

headline: A Life Story of Glitter and Tragedy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jobriath A.D.
summary_short: “Jobriath A.D.” is a documentary about a 1970s glam-rocker who came to a sad end.

headline: Curse of the Abominable Snow Mutants
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Glacier
summary_short: In “Blood Glacier,” people at an Alpine weather station face an onslaught of mutant creatures.

headline: Insert an Emoticon Here

summary_short: The comedy “Friended to Death” uses a noxious protagonist to look at social media.

headline: Looking for a Welcome in the American Melting Pot

headline: Revisiting Familial Territory

headline: On the Trail of a Gene That Kills

headline: To the Manner Born?

headline: A Penis With a Mind of Its Own

display_title: Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film
summary_short: The subtitle of the documentary “Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film” covers the facts.

headline: Hey, Evildoers, Here’s Webbing in Your Eye
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Amazing Spider-Man 2

headline: The Mysterious Adventure of the Good Night’s Sleep

headline: Nicaragua: In Shadows of Pain and Glory

headline: Hot Flashes? Great News.

headline: A Caper by the Coens, With a Fake Monet

headline: Something’s Burning, and Comedy Isn’t Pretty

headline: Enemies One Year, Teammates the Next

headline: Possessed by Demons, and a Nutty Professor

headline: Mind the Gap? That’s the Least of Their Worries

headline: Struggling to Escape the Bronx’s Grasp

headline: A Ferocious Satirist, With Ink as His Weapon

headline: Tiny Jockeys, Galloping in a Cloud of Despair

headline: Silent, Clumsy Avenger Gets to Work

headline: In a Scary Uniform, Subverting a March to Death

headline: Battling Illness and Royalty for Love

headline: A Badly Bruised Soccer Team Tries to Beat a Reputation

headline: Hating Humanity, on Two Wheels

summary_short: In Philippe Le Guay’s “Bicycling With Molière,” the chance to play Alceste in “The Misanthrope” tempts a retired actor.

headline: Bonding With the Chauffeur

headline: Love, and Warring Parents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 States

headline: Moving In? Beware the Other Residents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Haunted House 2
summary_short: Marlon Wayans stars in “A Haunted House 2,” his second stop in this horror-spoof franchise.

headline: Soaring Trips to a Temple in Nepal

headline: Competing to Be a Phallic Symbol

summary_short: In the documentary “The Final Member,” two men vie to have their penises entered into the Icelandic Phallological Museum as its first human specimen.

headline: A Lost Soul’s Wanderings

display_title: Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen of Pointe à la Hache
headline: Oil and Water Mix, Then Emotions Flare
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen of Pointe à la Hache
summary_short: The documentary “Vanishing Pearls” looks at the small Gulf community of Pointe à la Hache, La., where the oyster industry has been devastated by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

headline: Tip Well: It’s Your Waiter’s Last Night
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tasting Menu
summary_short: The romantic comedy “Tasting Menu” focuses on diners who are enjoying the final meals served in a closing restaurant.

headline: A Chip Off the Old Engine Block
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Small Time
summary_short: In Joel Surnow’s “Small Time,” a son opts for working at his father’s used-car business instead of going to college.

headline: After the Violence, the Real Pain Begins
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Proxy

headline: Gotta Dance (Together)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Make Your Move
summary_short: In “Make Your Move,” a rivalry between Brooklyn dance clubs, and their owners, threatens to keep apart two dancers who are meant to be together.

headline: Don’t Just Pass the Joint, Sell It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kid Cannabis

headline: A Plea for Equal Pay for Equal Pedaling

summary_short: In this documentary, Kathryn Bertine, an athlete and former ESPN columnist, questions the male-dominated world of professional cycling.

headline: In an Uneven Economy, an Opening in the Service Sector Beckons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fading Gigolo
summary_short: John Turturro stars in and directs “Fading Gigolo,” a comedy about a New Yorker who is losing his job and is urged to try prostitution.

headline: I Am My Own Monster (Technology Rules!)

summary_short: “Transcendence” stars Johnny Depp as an artificial-intelligence genius whose wife uploads his consciousness into a supermachine after anti-technology extremists shoot him.

headline: Taking the Man Out of Oklahoma, Maybe

headline: A Bear, Her Cubs and the Wilderness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bears

headline: He Took the Dare to Change His Life

headline: A Labor Leader’s Devotion to His Cause
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cesar's Last Fast
summary_short: “Cesar’s Last Fast,” about Cesar Chavez, centers on a 36-day fast he endured to call attention to farmworker conditions.

headline: Waiting for ‘Waiting for Guffman,’ Sort Of
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Authors Anonymous
summary_short: Writers in Los Angeles waiting to be published are the title characters in “Authors Anonymous.”

headline: That Thing He Had for the Boss’s Wife

headline: Two Artistic Outlooks, Heightened Side by Side

summary_short: Two artists, Mary Frank and Tacita Dean, play roles in two documentaries being shown together at Film Forum.

headline: His Résumé Before the Age of 4: ‘I Saw Jesus on a Horse’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heaven is for Real
summary_short: The 2010 best-selling book “Heaven Is for Real” has made it to the screen, starring Greg Kinnear.

headline: At One With Their Dogs, Growling and Snapping
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joe
summary_short: In David Gordon Green’s “Joe,” Nicolas Cage stars as a steely ex-convict who tries to help a boy with an abusive home life.

headline: The Question Is Whodunit; the Answer Is Clear
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unthinkable
