display_title: Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silence
headline: Breaking Silence on a Monk
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silence
summary_short: “Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silence” is a reverent collection of interviews and archival speeches about its subject, a Trappist monk.

headline: Lifetime Anguish Is the High Cost of Courage
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Railway Man
summary_short: Colin Firth stars as Eric Lomax, a British Army officer who served and suffered during World War II, in this movie based on Lomax’s memoir.

headline: An Alfresco Fling Beats Selling Tractors
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The King of Escape
summary_short: Alain Guiraudie’s “The King of Escape” follows a middle-aged gay tractor salesman who finds himself in a heterosexual mood after rescuing a teenage girl, so he runs away with her.

headline: A Man of God, and of Contradictions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Jewish Cardinal
summary_short: “The Jewish Cardinal,” by Ilan Duran Cohen, traces the life of the Jewish-born French cardinal, Jean-Marie Lustiger.

headline: Domesticated Macaws Reclaiming Their Wild Side
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rio 2
summary_short: In “Rio 2,” a mated pair of blue macaws and their brood leave Rio for the lush perils of the Amazon rain forest.

headline: Teenagers, Fed Up, Hatch a Deadly Plan
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Perfect Sisters
summary_short: In “Perfect Sisters,” based on a true story, two Canadian siblings decide to kill their mother.

headline: Art and Style Are Their Lifeblood
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Only Lovers Left Alive
summary_short: In “Only Lovers Left Alive,” Jim Jarmusch’s celebration of art and style, cultured vampires make up a kind of aesthetic aristocracy.

headline: Kitchen Table Anarchists Under Siege
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No God, No Master
summary_short: “No God, No Master,” starring David Strathairn, offers a sepia-toned account of the Palmer raids, a time of reds-under-the-bed hysteria and leftist persecution.

headline: Writing a Playbook That Ensures Glory
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Draft Day
summary_short: Kevin Costner plays the beleaguered general manager of the Cleveland Browns in “Draft Day.”

headline: On the Wall, Who’s the Deadliest One of All?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oculus
summary_short: Karen Gillan and Brenton Thwaites play siblings seeking clues to their parents’ fate in a tale alternating between time periods.

headline: Wooing the Boss With a Spicy Dance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cuban Fury
summary_short: In “Cuban Fury,” the British comic Nick Frost stars as a former child salsa-dancing champ who brushes up on his skills to woo his new American boss.

headline: Exploring the Blot on a Newspaper’s Record
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Fragile Trust
summary_short: Samantha Grant’s documentary, “A Fragile Trust,” comes a decade after the fraud scandal at The New York Times perpetrated by the reporter Jayson Blair.

headline: Don’t Hoodwink the Help, Dear
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hateship Loveship
summary_short: “Hateship Loveship” tells of a new housekeeper for a disturbed Iowa family and the damage that ensues when a prank is played on her.

headline: On-Camera Dating
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hank and Asha
summary_short: “Hank and Asha” is the story of an epistolary, long-distance romance that uses video recordings instead of pen and paper.

headline: Latin Rhythms, Exported to the Mideast
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dancing in Jaffa
summary_short: In “Dancing in Jaffa,” the ballroom dancer Pierre Dulaine, whose organization was featured in “Mad Hot Ballroom,” teaches Jewish and Palestinian youngsters steps and courtesies.

headline: That Bend in the River Might be Manufactured
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Watermark
summary_short: “Watermark” explores how water shapes us, and how we shape water, as the filmmakers travel across 10 countries.

headline: A Much Darker Hitchhiker’s Guide
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Skin
summary_short: In “Under the Skin,” Scarlett Johansson is an extraterrestrial femme fatale picking up, and disposing of, unsuspecting men in Glasgow.

headline: Oh, C’mon, You Make Pale Blond Girls Feel Tan
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Being Ginger
summary_short: In “Being Ginger,” a man searches for a woman who will like him for the carrot top he is.

headline: Hard Times Take Their Toll on a Singapore Family
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ilo Ilo
summary_short: “Ilo Ilo,” Anthony Chen’s first feature film, focuses on a middle-class family in Singapore facing uncertainty in a 1997 financial crisis.

headline: An Island Idyll Turns Sinister
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Blood
summary_short: When honeymooners in the Caribbean wind up entangled in a violent underworld, the actress Gina Carano puts her mixed-martial-arts skills to use.

headline: After the Indulgence of Young Lust, the Going Gets Tougher (and Rougher)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nymphomaniac: Volume II
summary_short: “Nymphomaniac: Volume II,” the second half of Lars von Trier’s tale of an aging sex addict, examines the risky fallout of her obsession.

headline: Courage, Loyalty, Honor, Kablooey
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain America: The Winter Soldier
summary_short: Producers describe “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” a sequel in the comic-book-based franchise, as a blend of action film and political thriller.

headline: Futzing and Flirting as Armageddon Unfolds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye World
summary_short: In “Goodbye World,” a violent breakdown in society prompts friends to reunite at the home of a couple who live off the grid.

display_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came to Eden
headline: Seeking Eden, They Fled to Far Isle; Hell Followed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came to Eden
summary_short: In the late 1920s and early ’30s, couples (and a threesome) moved to an uninhabited island in the Galápagos chain, a tale told in a new historical documentary.

headline: Halle Berry as a Woman of Many Faces
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frankie and Alice
summary_short: Ms. Berry is an exotic dancer who has mysterious blackouts in the Geoffrey Sax film “Frankie & Alice.”

headline: Winning Style Points on the Street
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flex Is Kings
summary_short: “Flex Is Kings” documents a dancing style that incorporates elements of several street moves like vogueing.

headline: A Family Finds There’s Something Out There
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alien Abduction
summary_short: A family has an adventure in “Alien Abduction,” a sci-fi film inspired by so-called sightings in the Brown Mountain area of North Carolina.

headline: Broadcast News: British Airhead Still Has a Platform
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alan Partridge
summary_short: Directed by Declan Lowney, “Alan Partridge” is the first feature film about the title character, a vapid, self-absorbed broadcaster long played by the British actor Steve Coogan.

headline: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
summary_short: “10 Rules for Sleeping Around,” about one couple who allow each other to fool around and another that doesn’t, combines nudity and jokes, but fails to be a sex comedy.

display_title: The Unknown Known: The Life And Times Of Donald Rumsfeld
headline: Not Giving an Inch in a Battle of Wits and Words
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unknown Known: The Life And Times Of Donald Rumsfeld
summary_short: In his documentary “The Unknown Known,” Errol Morris goes mano a mano with the former defense secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

headline: The Profits and Losses of Fugitive Tracking
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Retrieval
summary_short: In “The Retrieval,” written and directed by Chris Eska, a black youngster working for Civil War bounty hunters helps them capture black fugitives.

headline: Good Wine, Bad Companions and a Nude Stroll in an Olive Grove
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dom Hemingway
summary_short: “Dom Hemingway,” a violent British comedy, stars Jude Law as a recently released prisoner off to a French villa to get what’s coming to him — in a good way — from a gangland boss.

headline: A Rock Star and a Roadie, Brothers After All
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mistaken for Strangers
summary_short: A scruffy documentary of the band the National’s 2010-11 European tour is less about the music than about left-field interviews with bemused band members.

headline: Facing Eviction, He Can’t Resist a Dare
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cheap Thrills
summary_short: “Cheap Thrills” is a dark comedy about two friends who fall into a rough game with a wealthy couple they meet at a bar.

headline: A Boyhood Summer of Darkness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hide Your Smiling Faces
summary_short: Daniel Patrick Carbone’s haunting debut feature offers a dark vision of boyhood adventure in a great outdoors fraught with peril.

headline: Rain, Heavy at Times
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noah
summary_short: Russell Crowe stars in “Noah,” Darren Aronofsky’s adaptation of the Old Testament story, which brings blockbuster spectacle and narrative liberties to the story.

headline: When ‘Egyptian’ Just Meant Egyptian
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jews of Egypt
summary_short: The documentary “Jews of Egypt” focuses on a shift from tolerance to harassment and expulsions, starting in 1949.

headline: Nonstop Carnage, Indonesian-Style
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Raid 2: Berandal
summary_short: Neither the undercover drama in “The Raid 2” nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down its numerous bracing and bloody brawls.

headline: She’s Not Heavy, She’s My Bar Pickup
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Refuge
summary_short: “Refuge,” starring Krysten Ritter, depicts a young woman who finds a new boyfriend while raising her needy younger siblings.

headline: A Loopy Stalker, Protesting Her Innocence
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing Without You
summary_short: In “Nothing Without You,” a delusional woman who stalks powerful men is accused of a brutal killing.

headline: Dreamy Postcards From Limbo
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Go Down Death
summary_short: The director Aaron Schimberg forays into lo-fi anachronism in his new film, “Go Down Death.”

headline: He Died Laughing (Isn’t That Sweet?)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blumenthal
summary_short: In “Blumenthal,” family members react less than nobly when a garrulous playwright dies while laughing at one of his own jokes.

headline: Amid Chants of ‘¡Huelga!,’ an Embodiment of Hope
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cesar Chavez
summary_short: Diego Luna’s “Cesar Chavez” reconstructs the emergence of the United Farm Workers organization in the 1960s and focuses on the movement’s leader, who died in 1993.

headline: Gang Wars, Iraq Warfare
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greencard Warriors
summary_short: “Greencard Warriors” follows a family that will do almost anything for papers.

headline: The Nanny as Sphinx, Weaving Enigmatic Magic on the Sly
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Vivian Maier
summary_short: “Finding Vivian Maier” focuses on a mysterious nanny who photographed Chicago scenes in the 1950s and ’60s.

headline: Temptation in Suburbia, Amid a Midlife Crisis
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breathe In
summary_short: In “Breathe In,” directed by Drake Doremus, a marriage is threatened by a glamorous interloper who stirs up a quietly suffering husband’s deepest longings.

headline: Carnage and Chaos, Heavy on the Gore
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sabotage
summary_short: Arnold Schwarzenegger leads a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs in “Sabotage,” and the bodies and bullets fly.

headline: Brass Band of Brothers, a Dad’s Gift
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brothers Hypnotic
summary_short: In Reuben Atlas’s documentary about the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, the band’s musicians grapple with the ideals of the Chicago trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran.

headline: If Only Orson Welles Had Starred
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jodorowsky's Dune
summary_short: “Jodorowsky’s Dune” is a documentary about the Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky’s efforts in the 1970s to turn the science fiction novel “Dune” into a feature film.

headline: Strangers, but Their Eyes Meet on a Train to Paris
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just a Sigh
summary_short: In “Just a Sigh,” a middle-aged actress traveling from Calais follows an intriguing stranger to a funeral and starts an affair.

headline: Pursuing Sex With a Bad Boy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Felt Like Love
summary_short: “It Felt Like Love” considers the dangers of teenage desire through the experiences of a coltish 14-year-old girl who randomly fixes on a weed-smoking tough guy.

headline: Alone Then, Supported Today
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anita
summary_short: Freida Mock’s documentary about Anita Hill, who accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during his Supreme Court confirmation hearings, segues from 1991 to the present.

headline: An Empty Suit, but Such Fine Material
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The French Minister
summary_short: In “The French Minister,” Thierry Lhermitte embodies classy chaos in the title role of Bertrand Tavernier’s dry, sly farce about diplomatic life.

headline: An Irish Romance With an Uncertain Future
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stay
summary_short: In “Stay,” a young woman living in Ireland gets pregnant and heads back home to Montreal.

headline: You Load the Uzi, Honey
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rob The Mob
summary_short: Based on real-life events, Raymond De Felitta’s “Rob the Mob” centers on a Queens couple who go on a holdup spree at Mafia social clubs.

headline: Is It Raging Lust, or Youthful Angst? Either Way, She’s Taking a Beating
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nymphomaniac: Volume I
summary_short: In “Nymphomaniac: Volume I,” directed by Lars von Trier, Charlotte Gainsburg plays a woman who endures suffering in the pursuit of sex.

headline: Muppets, a Front for Bigger Schemes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Muppets Most Wanted
summary_short: “Muppets Most Wanted,” an international caper, includes shots at Russians and the sly skewering of our European allies.

headline: Review: In ‘Divergent,’ Jolted Awake by Fear and Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Divergent
summary_short: In its movie incarnation, Veronica Roth’s dystopian novel “Divergent” has high-stakes action, a gutsy teenage heroine who is an outlier, and romance between warriors.

display_title: From Both Sides of the Aegean
headline: Deportees as Pawns in a Zero-Sum Tragedy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Both Sides of the Aegean
summary_short: The documentary “From Both Sides of the Aegean” revisits the forced ouster of Orthodox Greeks from Turkey and Muslim Turks from Greece in the 1920s.

headline: A Cop With a Secret
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of McCanick
summary_short: Cory Monteith plays a street hustler in “McCanick,” the story of a cranky police detective (David Morse) with something to hide.

headline: The Cop and the Crook, Brothers at Odds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Ties
summary_short: Guillaume Canet’s remake of “Les Liens du Sang” follows two Italian-American brothers, on opposite sides of the law, in Brooklyn in 1974.

headline: Welcome Home. Just Avoid the Headgear
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Awakened
summary_short: “Awakened,” a thriller starring Julianne Michelle, follows a woman who has returned to her hometown to investigate her mother’s death.

display_title: American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs
headline: Tracing an Activist Through Decades
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs
summary_short: In “American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs,” the director Grace Lee chronicles the life of a 98-year-old woman of Chinese descent who shares her name.

headline: In Search of a Duck, and a Way Through That Awkward Age
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Birder's Guide to Everything
summary_short: This coming-of-age comedy, starring Ben Kingsley, is the first feature directed by Rob Meyer.

headline: Returning, in His Own Way, to the Killing Fields
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Missing Picture
summary_short: In “The Missing Picture,” the director Rithy Panh uses figurines and the usual documentary devices to relay his personal story regarding Cambodia’s killing fields.

headline: Boy Meets Girl; Boy Must Win Dad Over
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bewakoofiyaan
summary_short: In the Bollywood romantic comedy “Bewakoofiyaan,” a seemingly perfect love story hits the skids when the recession leaves the man jobless.

display_title: Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club
headline: A Cranky Bonding Agent for Society’s Oil and Water
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club
summary_short: Thrown together after their children misbehave in school, five very different women form a support group in “Tyler Perry’s The Single Moms Club.”

headline: A Documentary on Battling Addiction’s Powerful Pull
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Anonymous People
summary_short: Greg Williams directed “The Anonymous People,” a documentary about the stigma of substance abuse and the barriers to recovery.

headline: Writing a New Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shirin in Love
summary_short: In “Shirin in Love,” a young Iranian-American journalist who feels lukewarm about her fiancé rushes headlong into a relationship with the son of an interview subject.

headline: South Korean School for Scandal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tabloid Truth
summary_short: In the South Korean drama “Tabloid Truth,” the death of an actress linked to a married politician is only the start of the action.

headline: Their Life Is a Cabaret, With Freedom in Vulgarity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exposed
summary_short: Eight cabaret performers are profiled in “Exposed,” which features snippets of their performances, merging shock and showmanship.

headline: Preserving Culture in the Amazon
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Xingu
summary_short: “Xingu” tells how three brothers, hoping to protect indigenous people in the Amazon, helped create a sprawling national park in Brazil.

headline: Murder, Mentoring and Masochism in Japan
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guilty of Romance
summary_short: Sion Sono’s “Guilty of Romance” looks at three women — a detective, a literature professor and a wife — each with ties to episodes of sexual abuse.

headline: A Getaway Unravels the Ties That Bind
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Week-End
summary_short: In “Le Week-End,” Nick and Meg, a long-married couple, revisit Paris to try to put the spark back in their marriage.

headline: In Japan, Two Teenagers Bond in a Chaotic, Violent World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Himizu
summary_short: “Himizu,” directed by Sion Sono, is a futuristic, dystopian film set in the present, made soon after the 2011 earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan.

headline: Poignant in Tooth and Claw
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ernest & Celestine
summary_short: “Ernest & Celestine,” about a mouse and a bear, offers the childhood comfort of a miniature world.

headline: Oil Money, and Where It Flows
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Men
summary_short: Rachel Boynton’s documentary “Big Men” is about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana and the perfect storm of avarice that develops around it.

headline: A Local Girl Who Made It Returns
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Veronica Mars
summary_short: Fans wanted more of the canceled TV show “Veronica Mars,” and with the help of a Kickstarter campaign, much of the old cast, including Kristen Bell, is back in Neptune in a feature film.

headline: The Killer Online
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Den
summary_short: In “The Den,” directed by Zach Donohue, a graduate student researching video-chat culture witnesses a murder online.

headline: Young Drifter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cold Lands
summary_short: In “The Cold Lands,” an 11-year-old boy flees into the forest after his mother’s death, shunning society until he meets another drifter.

headline: Trying to Take What Isn’t Theirs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Art of the Steal
summary_short: In “The Art of the Steal,” Matt Dillon and Kurt Russell are half-brothers and part of an art theft ring.

headline: Fast Cars, and Racing for Revenge
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Need for Speed
summary_short: Aaron Paul stars in “Need for Speed,” a B movie based on a video game series that might be best seen at a drive-in.

headline: A Spelling Bee Bully With Decades on His Rivals
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Words
summary_short: “Bad Words,” Jason Bateman’s feature-directing debut, is a would-be gonzo comedy with a tough exterior and a marshmallow center.

headline: When Your Twin Is Far More Interesting
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enemy
summary_short: In “Enemy,” directed by Denis Villeneuve, Jake Gyllenhaal plays a history professor who sees his double and starts stalking him.

headline: Some Things Go Bump in the Daytime, Too
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark House
summary_short: “Dark House” is a horror movie with a rural setting by Victor Salva, director of “Jeepers Creepers.”

headline: A Tough Day Being French (She Needs a Cigarette)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On My Way
summary_short: Emmanuelle Bercot’s “On My Way” stars Catherine Deneuve as a woman who goes out for a pack of cigarettes and ends up driving all over rural France.

headline: Where Performance Enhancers Are Legal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Better Living Through Chemistry
summary_short: A rather dull married pharmacist (Sam Rockwell) and a gorgeous, equally married customer (Olivia Wilde) make for an explosive compound in “Better Living Through Chemistry.”

headline: A Pakistani Fiancé Meets the Indian Parents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Total Siyapaa
summary_short: In “Total Siyapaa,” an Indian woman brings her fiancé home to meet her family, a crew that seems more malicious than madcap.

headline: Bittersweet Chocolate on the Pillow
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grand Budapest Hotel
summary_short: On its surface, “The Grand Budapest Hotel” is a caper, but this Wes Anderson film is also concerned with a complicated slice of 20th-century European culture with some very ugly history.

headline: A Dog and His Boy Take a Joy Ride Through History
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Peabody & Sherman
summary_short: A supersmart dog and his adopted human son set out for time-traveling adventures in “Mr. Peabody & Sherman,” the 3-D, big-screen adaptation of Jay Ward’s animated cartoon.

headline: Double Time: Seeing a Ghost, Romantically
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Face of Love
summary_short: In “The Face of Love,” Annette Bening plays a widow who sees a man, played by Ed Harris, who’s a double for her dead husband.

headline: To Scientists in Pursuit, a Bit of Matter Is No Small Matter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Particle Fever
summary_short: “Particle Fever” is a Mark Levinson documentary that goes into detail about the Higgs boson particle and the structure of the universe.

headline: A Heavy Bass Beat, a Wreath of Smoke, an Aura of Sweat
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Interior. Leather Bar.
summary_short: This film creates a piece of social and sexual history by reshooting segments of the 1980 film “Cruising” that were lost after being cut.

headline: A Spiritual Adviser’s Help Is Twisted as He’s Tormented
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Repentance
summary_short: “Repentance,” starring Anthony Mackie and Forest Whitaker, examines the price of being a prophet.

headline: A Juvenile Justice System With Few Checks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kids for Cash
summary_short: The documentary “Kids for Cash” examines corruption in the juvenile justice system.

headline: The Damage That Good Can Inflict
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fatal Assistance
summary_short: “Fatal Assistance,” a documentary by Raoul Peck, chronicles the challenges and failures of rebuilding efforts in Haiti after the 2010 earthquake.

headline: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lunchbox
summary_short: The Lunchbox,” by Ritesh Batra, puts Old Hollywood style in a Mumbai that has escaped the cyber world.

headline: If You’d Like to Live, Best Not Look Inside
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bag Man
summary_short: “The Bag Man” stars Robert De Niro and John Cusack in a neo-noir about crooks in a cat-and-mouse game.

headline: Humanity, Enhanced, on a Russian Battlefield
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stalingrad
summary_short: “Stalingrad” includes two story lines in a narrowly focused 3-D depiction of the struggle for a city during World War II.

headline: The Greatest Story, Retold
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Son of God
summary_short: Adapted from “The Bible,” a History channel mini-series, “Son of God” depicts the last days of Jesus.

headline: Eggs Over Easy, With a Side of Weird
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Odd Thomas
summary_short: The hero of “Odd Thomas,” an adaptation by Stephen Sommers of the Dean Koontz novel, is a short-order cook who sees dead people and finds their murderers.

headline: An Unreliable Hero Aboard a Troubled Flight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Non-Stop
summary_short: Liam Neeson stars as an unsettled air marshal trying to prevent murders in the air in “Non-Stop.”

headline: So Blissfully Nestled in Her Web of Lies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Lives
summary_short: The drama “Two Lives,” with Juliane Köhler and Liv Ullmann, focuses on a happily married woman and apparent East German spy whose secrets threaten to destroy her family life.

headline: Child Genius Meets Middle-Age Kid
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of HairBrained
summary_short: In “HairBrained,” Brendan Fraser plays a 41-year-old failed gambler who goes back to school and befriends a 14-year-old genius.

headline: A Wasteland, With Aliens
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Almost Human
summary_short: Joe Begos’s horror movie “Almost Human” should not be confused with the Fox television drama of the same name.

headline: Waiting With Bittersweet Anxiety for Their Moment
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Standbys
summary_short: The director Stephanie Riggs follows the tribulations of three actors who are on call to step in for a star in a stage show.

headline: Recalling Velvet, Pretzels and Beer, She’s Still Here
